Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the number of people who will lose their individual coverage because of Obamacare. While the claim states that 300,000 people will lose their coverage, the expert's verdict mentions that "hundreds of thousands" of cancellation letters were sent out, indicating that the number may be higher than 300,000.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement in the claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence that the claim falters at times.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any evidence or sources to back up the claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the 300,000 people who will lose their individual coverage will not have health insurance next year. However, this assumption is not supported by evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide any alternative explanations for why people may lose their individual coverage.
